title: Junior .NET Developer Technical Assessment
description: 100 technical interview questions for Junior .NET Developer position

questions.question: What will be the output of the following code?
Which keyword is used to prevent a class from being inherited in C#?
What is the default value of a bool variable in C#?
Which of the following is a value type in C#?
What does the 'var' keyword do in C#?
options: Creates a dynamic variable whose type can change at runtime
Creates a strongly-typed variable where the type is inferred by the compiler
Creates a variant type that can hold any data type like object
Creates a constant variable that cannot be modified after assignment

questions.question: What is the difference between 'const' and 'readonly'?
options: const is runtime constant, readonly is compile-time constant
const is compile-time constant, readonly is runtime constant (set in constructor)
There is no difference, they are synonyms
readonly can only be used on static fields, const can be used on instance fields

questions.question: What is boxing in C#?
options: Converting a reference type to a value type
Converting a value type to the object type or any interface it implements
Encapsulating a field safely within a property
Allocating memory on the stack for a reference type

questions.question: Which operator is used for null-coalescing in C#?
What is the correct way to handle exceptions in C#?
What is the entry point of a C# console application?
What are the four pillars of Object-Oriented Programming (OOP)?
options: Interfaces, Abstract Classes, Static Classes, sealed Classes

questions.question: Which OOP principle allows a child class to provide a specific implementation of a method already defined in its parent class?
What is the difference between 'override' and 'new' keywords when used with methods in C#?
options: 'override' extends/replaces the base method, 'new' hides it entirely
'new' extends the base method, 'override' creates a new slot
'override' is for abstract methods, 'new' is for interfaces

questions.question: What will be the output when the code is executed?
options: Base (Method is hidden, reference is BaseClass)

questions.question: Which of the following statements about interfaces in C# is TRUE?
options: Interfaces can contain fields and constructors
A class can inherit multiple base classes but only one interface
Interfaces can have default method implementations (since C# 8.0)
Interface members are private by default

questions.question: What is encapsulation?
options: The ability of objects to take many forms
Bundling data/methods and restricting direct access to object components
Creating new classes from existing classes
Defining a blueprint for a class

questions.question: What is an abstract class in C#?
options: A class that cannot have any implementation code
A class that cannot be instantiated and may contain abstract members
A class that is automatically static and sealed
A class that must be inherited by structs only

questions.question: Difference between Abstract Class and Interface?
options: Abstract class supports multiple inheritance, Interface does not
Interface supports fields, Abstract class does not
Abstract class can have state (fields) and constructors, Interface cannot have state
They are exactly the same in modern C#

questions.question: What is the purpose of a constructor?
options: To destroy objects and free memory
To initialize an object and set initial state
To copy an object to another variable

questions.question: What access modifier allows a member to be accessed only within its own class and derived classes?
What is the difference between List<T> and Array?
options: Array is dynamic size, List is fixed size
List<T> is dynamic size, Array is fixed size
List<T> can define multiple types, Array only one

questions.question: Compare Dictionary<TKey, TValue> vs Hashtable.
options: Dictionary is type-safe (generic), Hashtable stores objects
Hashtable is type-safe, Dictionary stores objects
Dictionary allows null keys, Hashtable does not

questions.question: What is a HashSet<T> and when should you use it?
Which collection represents a First-In-First-Out (FIFO) structure?
Which interface is the base for all non-generic collections?
Which collection is best for Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) behavior?
What happens if you try to add a duplicate key to a Dictionary?
options: It creates a second entry with the same key

questions.question: What is LINQ in C#?
options: A database management system like SQL Server
Language Integrated Query - syntax to query data from collections, DBs, XML
A library for networking and HTTP requests
A testing framework for unit tests

questions.question: What is the difference between IEnumerable and IQueryable?
options: IEnumerable executes in-memory, IQueryable executes on database server
IQueryable executes in-memory, IEnumerable executes on database
There is no difference, they are interchangeable
IEnumerable is for write operations, IQueryable for read operations

questions.question: Which LINQ method is used to project valid into a new form?
What is deferred execution in LINQ?
options: The query is executed immediately when defined
The query is not executed until the result is enumerated
The query runs on a background thread
The query is skipped if data is invalid

questions.question: Which LINQ method returns the first element or a default value if empty?
How do you filter a collection using LINQ?
What is a DbContext?
options: A configuration file for database connection strings
A session with the database ensuring UoW and repository pattern
A tool for migrating SQL scripts
A representation of a single database table

questions.question: Explain difference between Eager Loading and Lazy Loading.
options: Lazy loads data immediately, Eager loads on access
Eager loading is obsolete in EF Core
Lazy loading is the default in EF Core

questions.question: What is a Migration in EF Core?
options: Moving data from one server to another
Code file representing changes to database schema to match C# model
A runtime error when schema doesn't match

questions.question: Which approach allows defining schema using C# classes?
What does AsNoTracking() do?
options: Deletes the entity from database without tracking
Returns entities without attaching to change tracker
Prevents other users from tracking the query

questions.question: How to perform a logical delete (Soft Delete)?
options: Add an IsDeleted flag and filter queries globally
Delete the row and move it to a history table

questions.question: What does .SaveChanges() do?
options: Validates the model but doesn't write to DB
Persists all tracked changes to the database
Saves the current transaction to a log file
Downloads the latest data from database

questions.question: Which LINQ method filters products by price?
questions.code:
// Option D:
var products = dbContext.Products.Where(p => p.Price > value).ToList();

questions.question: What does Include() method do?
options: Adds a new entity to the context
Includes a file in the project

questions.question: What is ASP.NET Core?
options: A legacy framework for Windows-only web apps
A cross-platform, high-performance, open-source framework for building modern cloud-based apps

questions.question: Explain MVC architecture.
options: Model-View-Component: A pattern for Blazor apps

questions.question: What is Dependency Injection (DI)?
options: A technique where dependencies are provided to a class

questions.question: What is Middleware in ASP.NET Core?
options: Software components assembled into an app pipeline to handle requests and responses

questions.question: Which service lifetime creates a new instance for every request?
What is `appsettings.json` used for?
How does routing work in Web API?
options: It maps HTTP requests to file paths on disk
It maps HTTP requests to Controller actions using templates
It maps DNS names to IP addresses
It redirects users to the login page

questions.question: How to return a 404 response?
How are REST APIs stateless?
options: They maintain user sessions in server memory
Client state is not stored on server; each request contains all info needed to process it
They update the database state frequently

questions.question: Which HTTP method is used to CREATE a resource?
Which HTTP method is used to UPDATE an existing resource?
What does HTTP Status Code 200 mean?
What does HTTP Status Code 404 mean?
What does HTTP Status Code 500 mean?
What distinguishes a URI from a URL?
options: URI is a resource identifier, URL is a location access type of URI
URL is for websites, URI is for files
URI is deprecated, URL is the modern standard

questions.question: Which is a best practice for RESTful URIs?
options: Use plural nouns and lowercase letters

questions.question: What is the key difference between REST and SOAP?
options: REST is XML-only, SOAP is JSON-only
REST is a stateful protocol, SOAP is stateless architecture
REST is flexible architecture, SOAP is strict XML protocol

questions.question: Can Ajax replace REST?
options: Yes, Ajax is a newer version of REST
No, Ajax is a client-side technique to make requests; REST is the server architecture
Yes, but only for mobile apps
No, REST is for databases only

questions.question: What is the difference between INNER JOIN and LEFT JOIN?
options: INNER JOIN returns only matching rows; LEFT JOIN returns all left rows + matches
LEFT JOIN returns matches only; INNER JOIN returns all rows
INNER JOIN keeps nulls, LEFT JOIN discards them

questions.question: What is a Primary Key?
options: A key used to encrypt the database
A unique identifier for each record in a table
A link to another table's data
The first column in any table

questions.question: What is Normalization?
options: Organizing data to reduce redundancy and improve integrity

questions.question: Why use an Index in SQL?
options: To speed up data retrieval operations
To speed up data insertion operations

questions.question: What is SQL Injection?
options: A way to speed up queries
A security vulnerability where malicious SQL is inserted into input fields

questions.question: How to prevent SQL Injection?
In a query with INNER JOIN, how many table scans are minimum performed?
options: 2 scans (one for each table in worst case)

questions.question: Difference between Delete and Truncate?
options: Delete is logged and allows WHERE; Truncate is faster/minimal logging, resets identity
Truncate allows WHERE clause, Delete does not
Delete drops the table structure, Truncate keeps it
Truncate is reversible, Delete is permanent

questions.question: Which constraint ensures non-null values?
What does UNION operator do?
options: Combines result sets vertically (Add rows) and removes duplicates
Combines result sets and keeps duplicates (UNION ALL)

questions.question: Output of: console.log(typeof null);
What is a Closure?
options: A function bundled with its lexical environment
A way to close a window

questions.question: Difference between '==' and '==='?
options: == checks value & type; === checks value only

questions.question: What is async/await?
options: Syntax for writing asynchronous code that looks synchronous
A method to pause the server

questions.question: Output of multiplier code?
questions.code:
const mul = x => y => x * y;
console.log(mul(2)(3));

questions.question: What is DOM?
What is the event loop?
options: A mechanism to handle synchronous code
A mechanism that handles async callbacks/promises in non-blocking I/O
An infinite while loop in the code

questions.question: Which keyword defines a constant in JS?
What is a Promise?
options: A guarantee that code will not fail
An object representing the completion/failure of an async operation

questions.question: How to convert JSON string to object?
What is Unit Testing?
What is the AAA pattern?
What is Mocking?
options: Simulating the behavior of real objects/dependencies in tests

questions.question: What is the goal of Integration Testing?
options: To verify that different modules/services work together correctly

questions.question: Which attribute identifies a test method in NUnit/xUnit?
What is the Singleton Pattern?
options: Ensures a class has only one instance and provides global access
Creates objects without specifying exact class

questions.question: What is the Factory Pattern?
options: Defines an interface for creating objects, letting subclasses decide which to instantiate
Provides a simplified interface to a complex system

questions.question: What is the Strategy Pattern?
options: Defines a skeleton of an algorithm
Defines a family of algorithms, encapsulates each one, and makes them interchangeable

questions.question: What is Dependency Injection?
options: A design pattern to implement IoC

questions.question: What is the Repository Pattern?
options: Abstraction layer between data access and business logic

questions.question: What are Generic Collections?
options: Collections that are type-safe and performant

questions.question: What does the 'yield return' statement do?
options: Returns a value and terminates the method
Returns an element to an iterator and saves current state for next call

questions.question: What is Reflection?
options: Inspecting or modifying code metadata at runtime

questions.question: What is a Delegate?
What are Attributes in C#?
options: Declarative tags conveying runtime info to behaviors

questions.question: What is the difference between Task and Thread?
options: Thread is a lower-level OS concept; Task is a higher-level abstraction managed by ThreadPool

questions.question: What is Exception Handling best practice?
options: Catch specific exceptions first, then general Exception; use finally for cleanup
Throw exceptions to the user UI directly

questions.question: What is string interpolation?
What is a Nullable type?
options: A type that cannot be null
A value type that can represent null

questions.question: What is the purpose of 'using' directive vs 'using' statement?
options: Directive imports namespaces; Statement defines a scope for IDisposable objects
Directive is for C++, Statement is for C#
Directive is for memory, Statement is for imports
